text: I think if I'd never played Terraria I might have liked this game, but to me (played before 1.0 and never went back), it was a pale imitation. Haven't been back because so many other games compete for my time, including the various Terraria updates ;)
author: k9wazere

text: I have no clue why, but in my head, this song would sound like a heavenly sounding version of Saria's Woods. I think it's reminding me of the Twilight Princess version of the song the most. But the song's really beautiful regardless

text: This song is very inspirational and gets my imagination running wild. Awesome upload brother

text: Curtis Schweitzer is going places.
author: Pulsar

text: I'm sorry, but I've heard this so many times that I hate it now. It's beautiful, but stale to me.
author: DAL_nug

text: Starbound gets reluctant love from me. The current unstable build is miraculous, but the progress has been much too slow. Even for an indie early access game. Whether it's dev laziness or whatever, more should have been completed by now. The current unstable branch is a large step in the right direction, but I fear that after the 1.0 release the game will stagnate for another year again, if not longer.
author: Braduk

text: Ahem.  My annoyances with the development cycle of the game aside, I really do love this theme.  It also reminds me a lot of Metroid Prime 3's Skyworld Elysia, except with a piano melody overlaid and a bit more of an uptempo beat to it.
author: Honatuto

text:
Wow, I'm seeing so much hate from early access players.

Have you guys worked in the gaming industry before? I'll assume you all didn't.
Indie games need patience and love, especially given how small the Starbound team is - I've been on some projects myself and I can assure you they're doing a great job for being so little. About that bio-luminescence and whole beach ball thing, I believe they just give one of these out from time to time because they do not take too much time and it shows the community they ARE still active. It's better than to have no info for 5 months straight.

To people complaining they used the money too "boo, change offices!" - They were working pretty far from each other and let me tell you, when the person you're working with is not in your timezone, life is hella hard for the project and the group in general. I'm glad the money I gave to the kickstarter helped their company grow, get together and get more productive.

Now, the game is in early access, of course it's incomplete. Why not waiting for the final version while playing with some of the community's mods or making hardcore runs with friends? If you wish for it to go faster, graduate some artsy/tech related school and go send them your resume.
author: Meishali

text: This is a beautiful composition.
author: Brian Trang

text: Starbound is something of a tremendous joke when it comes to development.  They've done some scummy things, such as "BRB taking Kickstarter money to change offices" and "We plan on having stable builds every couple of months" (and there hasn't been one since March.)  Sure, there are nightlies, but I can't play with my insular group of friends on those, and playing on stable leads to massive loading times on chunks while trying to explore planetsides (plus those of us with awful computers have issues on planets with pink skies, for some reason.)
author: Honatuto

text: It really is the worst. All I wanted was terraria in space. I suppose that's hard to do when a main part of terraria is building up your map, and with the limitless supply of worlds that starbound has it makes it feel pointless. The NPC's don't do anything to help with the story-less environment. If anyone can think of a way to fix this it'd be great.
author: Brig

text:
They have big ass issues keeping to one project. It's like they're trying to throw fifty things at you at once.
"Oh, we have beachballs!"
"BIOLUMINESCENCE "
"HEY LOOK, MOTHER SHIPS!!!!"
For the love of God just focus on one thing.

text: Abandoneware
author: ixekun

text: Like many people have pointed out, that is incorrect. They're working on a single fuck-huge content update instead of a bunch of little ones.
author: Marcus Dranz

text:
@Marcus Dranz
That was supposed to be released in september. They are lying.
author: Welderman
Marcus Dranz

text: The game was supposed to be finished in 2013, then this year for one. Secondly they were supposed to patch on a monthly basis, they haven't. Finally they promised a major patch in September, of which they never delivered. They have a small fanbase who are their internet defense force, denying this company of any wrongdoing whilst covering for their broken promises. They ban everyone that has legitimate (aka not trolling/flaming) criticism from their forums and lied about offering refunds after people wanted to take them up on their word. They have been nothing but unscrupulous and shady in their dealings and have only survived thus far by being skilled at lying.
author: Welderman

text: As for risk involved, the dev for that zombie game got away scot free with abandoning his game.
author: Welderman

text:
@BaronCreel
I gotta be honest, there've been enough abandoned games and shit devs lately that you're going to need to point the one you're talking about out for me.

I'll admit that, from how long we've been waiting for this patch, Chucklefish seems to have bitten off more than they can chew. But they're still chewing.
I bought into Cube World a while back. THAT game is fucking abandoned. I mean, I get it, they're a husband-and-wife dev team trying for a big sandbox-y sort of adventure game, but they haven't just been not adding or changing anything, they haven't been SAYING anything. For almost TWO. FUCKING. YEARS. Again, THAT is what it looks like when someone abandons a game.
I'm staying well away from the community bit because I learned ages ago that forums are terrible places. Most of them are just well-disguised powder-kegs waiting for someone thick or malicious enough to walk along with a bit of fire.
And that last bit of your post sounds incredibly hyperbolic, and more like you're talking about Garry's Incident than Starbound.
They've got far too much to lose, even if they wanted to be as Dick-Dastardly-dishonest as you're claiming, because they're not just a dev team, they're a publisher now as well.
It's been a shitty time for games lately and people are becoming far too quick in jumping to conclusions.
If you want to write it off now, fine. Go for it. I'm gonna stay right here. So I can have the patch when it comes out and have a good time. ..or be the first one there to slap them if they do cock up.
author: Marcus Dranz

text:
@Marcus Dranz
100% this.

My only response to the people complaining about these games being "unfinished" or "abandoned" is this; then why the holy hell did you buy a beta game that's currently in development? It's not like that fact wasn't plastered all over the Steam page. There's a certain risk that comes with these types of games, and you have to be smart when it comes to what to buy.

At least the dev team behind Starbound actually tries to be vocal about their development. That's better than most.

text: Also it isn't even out yet. You are just preodering and gaining access to the alpha. You are all one person right? There can't be this many people that are this specifically wrong.

author: Staringathesun

text: Not that impressed, tbh. It seems a lot of the core problems of the game are still their (bad combat system, lack of focus outside the beginning parts). Terraria still seems the plain better choice of the two.
author: Nathan Sifferath

text:
@Nathan Sifferath ... The combat is way better than Terraria's though. It's designed to be harder, which it does successfully. In terraria you either swing you sword, with no recovery time, or shoot arrows/bullets which can easily be hoarded. The magic is the only thing that's good about the game's combat imo. Not that I dislike it, but the combat is a weak point of terraria.

But they openly said they're planning on adding way more quests and shit to the mid and late game. They wanted early game stuff out of the way first, so they could see if we liked it. I do.
author: Nedoxu

text: Jokes on you! The game is now in 1.0, and is better than ever! It even has a story!
author: Some Polish Guy

text:
Jesus christ, how long has it been since I typed this out? I legitimately don't even remember. How did you even find this comment?

Anyways, the game is still shit. Look back at the original goals the dev team had written out, and compare it to what the game has now and the years it took to get it to the state it is in now. Incredibly embarrassing, they couldn't keep a simple schedule, and that is the big reason why Starbound is such a half-baked product. Nearly everything in the game could be done better by a more competent dev team (like, say, Re-Logic). I don't know anything about the story, but I'm going to guess it is both unnecessary and grindy to progress through. Tell me if I'm on the mark on that.
author: Nathan Sifferath

text: This game has an awesome soundtrack, I'm really blown away by all the great music indie games have been producing. I find this theme enchanting and quite addictive. Starbound seems to be heavily inspired by Terraria, and I like how you have your spaceship and you can explore different planets. It hasn't been released yet, but it's available through Early Access and has been quite popular for some time now.

author: Niclas

@nickebest

author: Welderman

text: Is it just me, or has the game industry been incredibly lucky when it comes to hiring composers? Maybe it's because I'm subscribed to a "best video-game music" list and not a "best movie music" one, but I've heard more creative and inspiring songs come out of video games, even the poorest of them (Tim Follin is relative to that point), than movie score and the music industry combined in the last decade. The bit-music genre couldn't have had a better start.
author: Jirt

text: @Mdude360 I think that's because movie music has to match what's going on on-screen to a larger degree. When a character starts running, the music's tempo has to match that. Video game music is made to be a pleasant tune in the background.
author: Mr Michael
